how would you describe your main use cas: Note-taking;Task and project management (including CRMs);As a knowledge base (including technical, non-fiction and encyclopaedic content);Producing/publishing interactive fiction;Worldbuilding (e.g. for role-playing games);Narrative fiction writing (either supporting its creation or directly writing in TiddlyWiki);Programming;Other
as you selected other: what are other pr: Internau corporate knowledgebase. Often for personal use at first and later for the entire team or department.
do you share your tiddlywiki(s) with oth: Yes, and I am the only editor/administrator of my wiki(s)
putting it all together, what value does: It helps in jotting down ideas, and work on it modularly. This saves a lot of time and lessen wasted resources. Depending on the project, it's either a supplement or the primary method side-by-side with traditional notebook notes and journals.
what is your level of ability with tiddl: I have customised TiddlyWiki through options and plugins;I am comfortable using WikiText widgets (e.g. <$transclude>, <$list>...);I am comfortable writing filter expressions;I have written custom HTML;I have written custom CSS styles
how do you save changes in tiddlywiki?: Single-file wiki through web browser with Download Saver (default saving mechanism);Single-file wiki with TiddlyDesktop
how do you back up/sync changes between: TiddlySpot / TiddlyHost;Consumer online storage (e.g. Google Drive, Dropbox);Web or cloud hosting (other than TiddlyHost/TiddlySpot e.g. Netlify, AWS, OVH, Google Cloud...);Neocities, Nekoweb, tiiny.host, omg.lol and similar services;DIY (any other solution)
as you selected diy, would be grateful f: Syncthing. It works cross-platform (Android, Linux, iOS, macOS, Windows). While Syncthing can be used to sync online too, it's best for LAN sync'ing. I leave online backups in MEGA Sync and pCloud monthly.

outside of plugins, palettes and other i: I added my preferred base CSS and font styles that I regularly use across different projects. Although the one I'm using for my TW sites are a bit old, since I'm still working on a fresh new one with only the latest in CSS and HTML.
what are we doing well? prompts for thin:
1. Very helpful and polite community. I'm an autistic, and a type of autistic who finds it hard to join in a new community even online. So, everyone being helpful and polite made it easy.
2. Broad-minded team. I asked about creating an English Philippines translation, and it was welcomed with open arms. Generally, it's denied in projects because there's British and/or American English already.
what could we do better? prompts for thi: Maybe the official documentation can also suggest other TW help/doc sites. The official docs is geared on the technical side, assuming one is in programmer mode. There are other TW help/doc sites written in a "How-To" way, or in wordy explanation way. It will help a wide range of users, as we all have different preferred way of learning.
with your consent, we would like to publ: Yes, I am happy for my responses to be published
